For now, I would avoid employment until they are more stable.

review_title: You don't want to work here.
pros: Compensation is high for the area. 401(k) match is honestly pretty good.
cons:
Morale right now is awful.  I don't know a single person who is happy here.  Management keeps cutting more people every month and piling on more work to a leaner staff.  There's only so far you can cut before the system breaks.

Senior management is a joke.  They have implemented multiple internal projects to make the company a 'high performing organization,' but no one has bothered to collect any input as to how we currently execute projects or what will and won't work.  The result is a broken system that will set up all future projects to fail.  And anyone who speaks up and says it isn't going to work is laid off the next week.  We won't be able to execute a single project in three years - mark my words.

The only thing worse than senior leadership is HR.  They keep a death grip on every group, tieing lower management's hands behind their backs, making it impossible to manage their teams effectively.  Any internal move must be lateral - no promotions - and your average promotion for high performers is 4-5 years.  The only way to climb the ladder is through the graces of your direct supervisor.  Luckily, lower management understands how bad it is and goes to bat for us, but they are told no by their leadership.  Plus, they are not given adequate budgets to properly reward their employees.  The result is high turnover as young engineers come here and stay 1-2 years before realizing what a train wreck this place is, while 50+ year old employees are just holding on for their pensions.  Everyone in the middle has been laid off.

Average raises are 2.5% - 3% and promotions are under 5%.  Yet every year we are told it is a record breaking year.  Abysmal.

Last thing - the layoff culture here is bad.  Do your research before taking a job here; people are laid off every month.  I have heard stories of people not even being told in person - they receive a phone call after hours telling them to not come in the next day.  In some cases, even direct supervisors are not told their employees were let go.
